description:
Cellvibrio fibrivorans is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Cellvibrio. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Cellvibrio fibrivorans is known for its ability to degrade cellulose, a complex carbohydrate found in plant cell walls.

The cells of Cellvibrio fibrivorans are typically rod-shaped and measure approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.5-3.0 μm in length. They are motile, possessing a single polar flagellum, which allows them to move through their environment.

Cellvibrio fibrivorans is considered an important cellulose-degrading bacterium due to its ability to produce a range of cellulolytic enzymes, including endoglucanases, exoglucanases, and β-glucosidases. These enzymes work synergistically to break down cellulose into simpler sugars, which the bacterium can then use as a carbon and energy source.

The habitat of Cellvibrio fibrivorans is typically found in soil, decaying plant material, and other environments rich in cellulosic substrates. Its ability to degrade cellulose makes it a key player in the carbon cycle, contributing to the recycling of organic matter in natural ecosystems.

Overall, Cellvibrio fibrivorans is a versatile and ecologically important bacterium that plays a crucial role in the decomposition of plant-based materials in the environment.
